The hip hop collective Cartel del Santa takes its name from a barrio called Sante Catarina, a working class suburb in the shadow of the city's industrial smokestacks and factories.
Cartel's leader is MC Babo (ph).
(Through Translator) That's how our group came to be, rapping about gangs, about drugs, living in the barrios.
Our music was about our small little corner of Nuevo Leone.
In Santa there are no yuppies or people with money.
They were all field workers and factory workers.
It was the ghettos of Los Angeles, only with factories.
Monterrey has become the center of Mexican hip hop.
The members of Cartel del Santa live together and record in a rented house they call Casa Babylonia.
The tattooed MC Babo loses his rapper's swagger and takes on the language of a CEO as he talks about his plan to take advantage of changes in the Mexican music industry.
(Through Translator) After three CDs, my role with the label is going to change.
Last year I was just an artist on the label.
Now I'm a business partner with the label.
I make the songs.
I compose them.
I produce them.
I own them.
It gives me a bargaining position.
If it is not agreeable to me, I walk away.
I know what's best for my product, because I'm the one who is creating.
(Soundbite of Cartel del Santa)
MC Babo may be in the right place at the right time to take on the Mexican record business.
Industry observers estimate the major labels and their artists are losing 50% of their sales to piracy.
In Mexico it's not unauthorized downloading, but illegal CDs sold in shops and on street corners all over the country.
The crisis is loosening the control the majors hold over the industry.
A few years ago, it was almost impossible for a new band to get heard on the radio, sold in record stores or tour if it wasn't signed to a major label.
Ricardo Hass (ph) manages the rock band Baquerro.
The veteran of the Mexican music industry says bands are figuring out new ways to get audiences to pay for their music.
Bands know that they can work with a do- it-yourself approach or an independent weight approach that works.
The majors, the indies, the do-it-yourselves, they're going to meet.
There are now new ways of developing artists that the majors are trying to be signed.
So it's like some sort of a strange marriage between the major label and the independent artists or the do-it-yourself artists.
And those musicians are everywhere.
Even a casual stroll from Barrio Antigo along a deserted commercial strip yields a musical performance.

A trail of teenagers on the way home from a Barrio Antigo nightclub is beat boxing.

(Through Translator) The people of Monterrey are very expressive, and in music they find what they need, love, tenderness, disaster.
Whatever life throws at you, it's there in music.

And now a window into Washington politics.
Like two bickering spouses, the Republican and Democratic leaders in the Senate have been embroiled in a public argument that's dragged on for weeks.
This past Friday it suddenly came to an end.
The squabble was over how many Republicans and Democrats should be named to a conference committee.
Its task is to iron out differences with the House on legislation obliging firms to get their pension funds up to date.
NPR's David Welna reports, it took a seasoned veteran of such battles to end the standoff.
In the Senate, if both sides in a dispute can't reach an agreement, things usually end up going nowhere.
And that's just where things seemed to be headed when on Friday, Democratic Minority Leader Harry Reid squared off once again as he had all week long with Majority Leader Bill Frist.
Reid said he'd settle for eight Republicans and six Democrats, rather than seven Republicans and five Democrats on the conference committee.
What we're saying is let's have another Republican and another Democrat.
Or two more Republicans and two more Democrats.
You'll still be a two vote margin the Republicans have.
But Frist insisted it would be seven Republicans, five Democrats.
Just so that people understand, the seven to five ratio, which I've been clear with for weeks now, does allow for equal participation between those two committees, so the fairness is seven-five.
At this point, Reid noted that the Republican whom Frist had replaced as Majority leader had joined the fray.
I see on the floor the distinguished Junior Senator from Mississippi, who was the Majority Leader and Minority Leader in years passed.
He could write it.
Well, he has written a book, about how difficult it is.
In fact, Lott's book about his downfall as Majority Leader says some rather nasty things about Frist.
As for Reid's reminder of his lowered status, Lott tried to make light of it.
I really enjoy being referred to as the Junior Senator from Mississippi, which I am, and it makes me feel so young.
But Lott also made it clear he's seen more effective leadership in the Senate.
I've never seen this happen before.
Never.
Not one time when I was Majority Leader did the Minority Leader and I not come to an agreement on a number to go to conference.
As Frist left the chamber, Lott turned to Reid and made him an offer.
Okay, so we're at loggerheads here.
We shouldn't be.
I got a novel idea.
Go up to nine-seven, or go down to six-four.
I'll take it.
Nine-seven, you've got a deal.
How about six-four?
You got it.
Nine-seven, you've got a deal
No wonder Reid leaped at Lott's offer.
You don't need to be a math whiz to realize the ratio of nine to seven favors the minority more than seven to five.
The question was whether Frist would give in.
His answer came two hours later on the Senate floor.
And the Senate insists upon its amendment, request a conference with the House and the Chair be authorized to appoint conferees at a ratio of nine to seven.
Frist, it was clear, had blinked.
Perhaps he was weary or perhaps he was saving his strength for fighting other battles.
And there will surely be more in an election year in which control of the Senate hangs in the balance.
David Welna, NPR News, the Capitol.
